students.description: This project aims to show the difference in the number of museum artifacts that are in an exhibit versus in storage across various institutions under the Smithsonian umbrella. Museums are often limited in what they can show by the amount of floor space, leaving the visitors to see just the tip of the iceberg. By exploring the different institutions and the topic categorization of the artifacts, patrons interested in the Smithsonian can get a better understanding of what the museums have to offer and what they’ve chosen to promote. Hovering over the different “pinnacles” reveals the percent of artifacts from that particular museum that are either on view (above water) or in storage (below water).
students.name: Amina Brown
students.subtitle: Invisible Artifacts
students.title: Invisible Artifacts

students.description: This project investigates the collection of pinback buttons in the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The buttons are displayed on a timeline to show the visual impact they have and how political and social justice movements have used the medium from the mid-1950s on.
students.name: Amina Brown
students.subtitle: Pushing Buttons
students.title: Pushing Buttons

students.name: David Malary
students.subtitle: African American heritage & The Smithsonian
students.title: African American heritage & The Smithsonian

students.description: This project proposes a unique user-driven way of browsing a museum collection in the digital space. Mexican Masks in the Smithsonian Institution Archives were chosen as the subject matter because humans have extremely high recognition of faces even when presented at lower resolution as seen in the mosaic. It’s worth noting that the allusion of having a mask masked by another mask was also considered as a design choice. A Mosaic was created using the base p5js library in order to realize these goals. Elements of interactivity were introduced so that users can select any of the ‘small images’ to force a redraw where that image was the ‘main mosaic image’. This allows individuals to jump through different images of museum items based on their desire to manifest realistic mask mosaics. Furthermore a bounded scroll window was created so that users can zoom in to the mosaic to view the ‘smaller images’ at full resolution.The result is a digital experience that allows users to browse the collection of masks through the lens of their curiosity.
students.name: Dallas Alberti
students.subtitle: Exploring the Smithsonian Archive of Mexican Masks with an Interactive Mosaic.
students.title: A Manifestation of Masks

students.description: The Face Value of Portraits visualizes the physical dimension of portraits at the National Portrait Gallery, with an interest in the gender difference in the collection.  A few pre-curated salons are available, reflecting data about a portrait’s physical dimension, the year of completion (from 1710s to 1960s) and the gender being portrayed. The project started with a question whether a portrait - its existence and size - would signal a portrayed figure’s social status. The visualization method is inspired by salon-style-exhibitions where visitors can compare the physicality of artworks in a single gallery space.
students.name: Inhye Lee
students.subtitle: The Face Value of Portraits
students.title: The Face Value of Portraits

students.description: I discovered while searching the Smithsonian API that many of Carl Newman's nude drawings are faceless. I decided to expand this project after getting comments on this discovery to see if this pattern holds true with other artist’s nudes. This project is an observation piece uncovering the many drawings of faceless nudes in the Smithsonian. It touches on the objectification at hand by comparing faceless nudes to highly detailed breasts. I hope this project makes people think about this topic and maybe discover even more faceless nudes outside of the Smithsonian.
students.name: Isabel Stoddart
students.subtitle: Faceless Nudes
students.title: Faceless Nudes

students.description: For this visualization I wanted to show how women in the Smithsonian are represented through the topics they are tagged with. I looked at the portraits of women in The National Portrait Gallery. I chose to look at portraits because historically portraits were only painted of prominent figures and I wanted to see which women were classified as important enough to have a portrait made of them and why. The visualization is split up into a graph showing a count of the number of portraits with each topic and a gallery of portraits split up by year.
students.name: Isabel Stoddart
students.subtitle: What Makes a Woman?
students.title: What Makes a Woman?

students.description: An Interactive map and visualization tool for exploring The Smithsonian Museum of Natural History's Mineral Sciences collection. The Smithsonian Museum of Natural History's Mineral Sciences collection consists of hundreds of thousands of gems and minerals. The museum's digital archives provided geolocation points and other data for the 656 items found in the interactive map featured here. The visualization at bottom left portions out the collection into a set of common colors, and allows you to explore the material accordingly. This involved creating a node script that analyzed the the text descriptions of each gem and sorting them by key words matched to 20 different color groups. With numerous ways of describing something that is "yellowish green", this helped to make the data more accessible while also giving the user a general idea of the over all shape, or in this case, "color" of the data. All items link directly to the collection record on the museum's website. This is especially helpful for the many items to which image rights applied. I learned over time that the structure of the Smithsonian's returned API data required a more adaptive approach to the data analysis than the rigid criteria I had begun with. For example, looking for the carat weight value in the same exact location of the data would often return "null" values. Generalizing the search queries, in addition to creating a placeholder graphic for items with rights-managed images allowed me to broaden my dataset as much as possible without encountering any "null" values or other missing pieces. This was especially important for the map, where the sparseness of the available data could quickly become an issue.
students.name: James Troxel
students.subtitle: Smithsonian Rock Ranger
students.title: Smithsonian Rock Ranger

students.description: Visualizing patterns across the Smithsonian’s cultural collections. Associated with History (shown) analyzes the individuals most represented within the National Museum of American History. Connected Culture explores topics shared across the Smithsonian's cultural institutions. The Shape of Time highlights the decades most represented in the Open Access collection.
students.name: Justin Kraus
students.subtitle: Defining Culture
students.title: Defining Culture

students.description: Seeing through the eyes of various collections at the Smithsonian. The following 50 items span across 9 different museums and various departments at the Smithsonian. Through the objects we get a sense of the breadth of various collections, and an appreciation for the objects, fossils, animals, marine life, and historical artifacts curated and collected over centuries. The objects below span thousands of years, from the current day to 2500 BCE. Using the Smithsonian's Open Access Portal , we work through the various collections.
students.name: Lee Kuczewski
students.subtitle: The Eyes of The Smithsonian
students.title: The Eyes of The Smithsonian

students.description: This visualization is a graphical representation of one of the Quipu in the Smithsonian collection. Quipu (also written Khipu) were an ancient record keeping device created in Central and South America by indigenous Andeans, prior to Spanish colonization. Of the twenty or so in the Smithsonian collection, this was the only one that was also included in the external Khipu Database Project, run by Harvard researcher Gary Urton. This external database allowed me to use the data in an excel format to create the visualization. The aim of the project is exploratory in nature, and hopefully aids in a basic understanding of how these recording devices used knots to keep track of numeric data. Eventually I would love to include more of the qualitative aspects of these devices, such as cord material and color.
students.name: Ripley Cleghorn
students.subtitle: Quipu
students.title: Quipu

students.description: This project is a visual biography of the life of the first American woman to go to space, Sally Ride. The project focuses on her first mission in detail, and incorporates other parts of her life in a condensed manner. In addition to text, images of objects belonging to Sally Ride (courtesy of the Smithsonian open access API) as well as pictures of the mission (courtesy to NASA) help to enrich the storytelling. The biography centers around a timeline that is interactive and allows users to keep track of which part of her life they are reading about (as well as allows users to click on specific years of interest).
students.name: Ripley Cleghorn
students.subtitle: Sally Ride
students.title: Sally Ride

students.description: Is the Constitution a living document? If so, then can it be visualised as such? I believe that the question can be better engaged with if it could be visualised as such. Tracking changes and “evolution” in text documents is important endeavour and one which has many solutions. Computer scientists and programmers, for example, use git to track changes in their codes repositories which are more often than not, entirely text-based. This gives us on opportunity to use the same mechanism for tracking changes the constitution. Git’s version control allows tracking changes in a text document as it evolves; it tracks deletions, additions, and even follows separate silos in which draft is being developed via branches. I use git branches to visualise the changing text: in tree graphs and more specifically a directed acyclic graph . Each node represents a commit, version in time of the text - with major changes, such as an amendment, being developed in a separate branch, and then pushed back into the main branch as a a new commit.
students.name: Shaheryar (Sherry) Manzar
students.subtitle: Git Constitution
students.title: Git Constitution

students.description: This project is showing you things that haven’t received enough attention and highlight. Firstly, I scraped all the works throughout Smithsonian Library. For the search queries, the synonyms of ‘WASTE’ were used. I used the synonyms from google synonym search for making ‘search term’. Then tied the garbage icons floating into the pieces having the keywords. Then created a museum comprised of the ‘unwanted object’. The collections of the garbage-like objects are like the images collection like above. As the user scrolls, the objects turns into the anonymous squares as the users used to see the pieces. By showing this visual, this project wants to convey the message that the unwanted objects are seen as mere ‘anonymous’ / ‘unattended’ objects. At the final stage, this visualization eventually creates the museum of ‘waste’ using a visual metaphor of ‘garbage bin’.
students.name: Seungyu Paik
students.subtitle: Museum of Waste
students.title: Museum of Waste

students.description: History is a record of what people are interested in. And how history is recorded has been changing over time with the advance of techonolgy as well. In  very older times, the mural was used to record what they had experienced. Then, the media has evolved to books and paintings or other form of art. The area of interest has been evolved over time as well. It had been geographically limited at the beginning. However, as more interactions became possible throughout a wider range of area, people started to record region where they couldn't have been obsereved before. This project specifically focuses on film-related archival media to show how history was recorded during modern times. By gathering geographycal information and type of media information, it shows which part of the world was the point of interest over time and, in each time, what medium was used for documentation chronically are visualized.
students.name: Seungyu Paik
students.subtitle: Mapping Human History Through Media
students.title: Mapping Human History Through Media

students.description: When brainstorming ideas for this project, I searched the stacks of Smithsonian collections for Mexican related entries. Many of the results were music related. When I followed the source of the entries, I found Folkways Recording - a collection of world music and sounds. This project displays popular songs from Mexico in an auditory tour through the country by genre. The visualization is built using D3 and wavsurfer.js, with a special emphasis on quality scrollytelling techniques.
students.name: Tiffany France
students.subtitle: Mexican Folk Music
students.title: Mexican Folk Music

students.description: Is there a difference in tagged topics for women versus men? This visualization shows topics by gender using the Smithsonian API. Results were gathered from four Smithsonian Institute units: the National Museum of American History, the American Art Museum, the Portrait Gallery, and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. Posts were gathered by pulling data on 20 names - ten female and ten males: Mary, Elizabeth, Anna, Helen, Margaret, Sarah, Emma, Susan, Clara, Florence and James, John, William, George, Joesph, Charles, Robert, Henry, Edward, Thomas. These names were chosen because they were the most popuar names as reported on the Social Security Administration website for last 200 years. Certain names were filtered out due to their lack of data in the Smithsonian collection. Even though the top ten names for each gender were used, the stacks returned far more entries for men than women. When posts were modified and cleaned, the total results showed more than 10x more posts for males than females.
students.name: Tiffany France
students.subtitle: Gender Tagging
students.title: Gender Tagging

students.description: This visualization is focusing on the history of aerospace industry in the past 120 years. The visual content base on numerical and categorical data of aircrafts that have been archived by the Smithsonian Open API, which can give people a review of technological and industrial revolution. Meanwhile, a location-based application with time-based element will bring a detailed analysis to tell a story of the whole industry including how the development trends changed in different time periods.
students.name: Yujun Jiang
students.subtitle: Reviewing the trends of aerospace industry (design + innovation) in the past 120 years
students.title: A History of Aerospace Industry

students.description: Nowadays, many bird populations are declining worldwide. Some of these species have not been sighted for many years and may already have succumbed. We introduced the image of a whirlpool as a metaphor in the natural world to simulate the course of extinction. Each data point in this visualization is not just a datum but lives that are moving away from us.
students.name: Zhibang Jiang
students.subtitle: A Growing Whirlpool: Conservation Status of Avian Species
students.title: A Growing Whirlpool: Conservation Status of Avian Species

students.description: Visualizing sound levels across twelve spaces. A first pass proof-of concept for a platform/tool in which museums could record ambient sound in their galleries and upload photos of the spaces to generate audio visualizations.
students.name: Brad MacDonald
students.subtitle: Ambient Sounds
students.title: Ambient Sounds

students.description:
Apples appear in many religious traditions, often as a mystical or forbidden fruit. Renaissance painters may also have been influenced by the story of the golden apples in the Garden of Hesperides. As a result, in the story of Adam and Eve, the apple became a symbol for knowledge, immortality and temptation.

Do artists just pick apple as a random fruit to depict in their artworks or is it highly associated with cultural significance? If it is then within Met’s collection, which continent uses apple as a metaphor more than others? And which media is more popular being used to depict apples?
students.name: Xingwei Huang
students.subtitle: Apple of My Eyes
students.title: Apple of My Eyes

students.description: Apple of The Met is an interactive counter piece for the Apple of My Eyes. Through this linear narrative journey audience can look closer and appreciate each apple which usually have been ignored from the frame. Also dive into different aspects of apples inside met collection to see which culture uses apple more frequently than the other.
students.name: Xingwei Huang
students.subtitle: Apple of The Met
students.title: Apple of The Met

students.description: I wanted to explore the idea of colonialism through the use of language on The Met’s website. I spoke with a number of museum writers about the language they avoid when writing copy for exhibitions and narrowed the list down to exotic, primitive and Oriental. I was ready to develop a web scraper then realized The Met has a really robust search function on their website that includes filters for department. The results were both unsurprising and surprising. I expected there to reveal usage of these words but was shocked by the prevalence of the word primitive, and that all but 300 of its 3506 uses appears in the Arts of Africa, Oceania, and the Americas department.
students.name: Brad MacDonald
students.subtitle: Artifacts of Colonialist Language
students.title: Artifacts of Colonialist Language

students.description: Buddhas at The Met is a data visualization project studying the facial features of Met's collections of buddha sculptures, through computer vision imaging processing. This project seeks to understand how buddha sculptures reflect the religion's process of morphing and changing to adapt to different countries and cultures.
students.name: Dan Ran
students.subtitle: Buddhas at The Met
students.title: Buddhas at The Met

students.description: The sound of ceramics makes each of them unique. In The Met, it is not possible to knock on the collections to hear their sound. With this web app (designed for the best experience on tablets), you will be able to create your own beat sequence with the typical sound of each ceramic type. Each pad cell will display an object in the corresponding type.
students.name: Zui Chen
students.subtitle: Ceramic Beats
students.title: Ceramic Beats

students.description:
Richard Serra, the conceptual sculptor, famously said “Drawing is a verb”,
and created his famous work on paper called 'Verblist' (1967), in which he compiled a series of verbs called "actions to relate to oneself, material, place, and process."

Can a search using a verb uncover the processes artists 'DO' to make art?
students.name: Janice Yamanaka-Lew
students.subtitle: Chasing Verbs-Searching The Met Collection through the Eyes of an Artist
students.title: Chasing Verbs

students.description: The vast size of The Metropolitan Museum of Art's collection presented the opportunity to utilize it as a proxy for understanding the interaction of civilizations over time. I was interested to learn if its almost 500,000 objects contained a hidden story that could be uncovered with visualization techniques.
students.name: Dan Grunebaum
students.subtitle: The Met: A Culture Timeline
students.title: Culture Timeline

students.description: Healthy oceans are sign of a healthy planet. This visualization attempts to showcase the story of dying oceans by exploring contents of the painting “Ocean Life” by James M. Sommerville.
students.name: Saloni Naishad Shah
students.subtitle: Disappearance
students.title: Disappearance

students.description:
Introducing the PHI finder App.  A single number, 1.618 or 'Phi' is a concept in its simplest form that refers to the Golden Ratio - a division of a line segment into a  unique ratio that gives us satisfying proportions.  Great art consistently captivates us.  Lets' see if this app can show us why?

* it may take awhile for the URL to load, please be patient - or go to the website to see the video.
students.name: Janice Yamanaka-Lew
students.subtitle: Does Math Collide with Art?
students.title: Does Math Collide with Art?

students.description: This project explores how medieval foot soldier arms and armor evolved throughout the centuries.
students.name: Antonie Dreyer
students.subtitle: Evolution of Arms and Armor
students.title: Evolation of Arms and Armor

students.description: How does the theme of the annual Costume Institute exhibition, contribute to the visual identity? To explore this topic, I created a colour analysis to evaluate the associations of the colour based on the theme and question how the exhibitions compare over a five-year period of time. Due to this time span, I am comparing Camp: Notes on Fashion (2019), Heavenly Bodies: Fashion and the Catholic Imagination (2018), Rei Kawakubo/Comme des Garcons: Art of the In-Between (2017), Manus x Machina: Fashion in an Age of Technology (2016) and China: Through the Looking Glass (2015).
students.name: Lulu Tanenbaum
students.subtitle: Exhibition Palettes: The Costume Institute
students.title: Exhibition Palettes

students.description: Fender and Gibson defined the sound of rock. Explore the ties between the two legendary guitar makers and rockstars featured in The Met’s “Play it Loud” exhibition.
students.name: Dan Grunebaum
students.subtitle: Fender vs Gibson: The Great Guitar Debate
students.title: Fender vs Gibson

students.description: Happle is a further branch out of the Apple of The Met, it works as the digital complement for the website. While previous website design presents users with a story about apple. This app helps visitors in the offline experience of navigating inside Met to find Apple. This app emphasizes at different parts of the content based on whether the user is currently inside or outside The Met Museum
students.name: Xingwei Huang
students.subtitle: Happle
students.title: Happle

students.description: The Landscape Generator is an interactive website made to encourage the user to engage with landscape paintings from The Metropolitan Museum of Art's collection in a new and unusual way, leading them to discover details about the art they may overlook with a traditional view. As an evolution to the Landscape Generator, a large format poster visualization continues to explore the collection of generated slivers by showcasing all available pieces in various grouped assortments.
students.name: Amanda Anderson-You
students.subtitle: Landscape Generator & Exploration Poster
students.title: Landscape Generator & Exploration Poster

students.description: This is an interactive project based on Met's instruments collection. The project aims to provide the audience with a sensual association between the 24 instruments and their sounds.
students.name: Dan Ran
students.subtitle: Let the music play!
students.title: Let the music play!

students.description: This is an AR interactive experience prototype based on The Met’s Mask collection.
students.name: Dan Ran
students.subtitle: Met Masquerade
students.title: Met Masquerade

students.description: All three projects explore how to search and push Met's collection in different ways.
students.name: Xingyang Cai
students.subtitle: The Trilogy of The Met search engine
students.title: Met Search Engine

students.description: We all have things in common, we might be the same age, born in the same place, we went to the same college; the possibilities are almost endless. The same theory can be applied to the artworks in The Met collection. MET Stories creates allows to user to pick a topic to see a dynamically generated timeline and story linking all of the artworks together through time, people, places and content.
students.name: Neil Oliver
students.subtitle: MET Stories
students.title: MET Stories

students.description: The Met is a pivotal example of a legacy museum. The collection is vast and encompasses some of the most fundamental pieces of art and artifacts. However, the negative connotations of legacy can suggest traditional standards or practices, which might not suggest the new nuances of contemporary art. This led to my questioning for this quantitative data visualization; has The Met adopted new media art? What types of new media art do they collect? What is the makeup of this collection?
students.name: Lulu Tanenbaum
students.subtitle: Has The Met adopted New Media Art?
students.title: New Media Art

students.description: This project explores what the entire MET collection consists of and how much of it is there.
students.name: Antonie Dreyer
students.subtitle: Quantifying The Met Collection
students.title: Quantifying The Met Collection

students.description: Three works of art from The Met’s collection, ranked via survey by 30 respondents. A proof-of-concept test of a larger idea in which users rank art on a live website and this data is collected and visualized.
students.name: Brad MacDonald
students.subtitle: Rated Art
students.title: Rated Art

students.description: This project explores the qualities of Rembrandt's self-portraits to understand the artist and the cultural context of Dutch impressionism.
students.name: John Outwater
students.subtitle: Rembrandt : Zelfportrets
students.title: Rembrandt : Zelfportrets

students.description: The evolution of color in The Met's European Paintings collection across time and artistic movements.
students.name: Nour Zein
students.subtitle: Rich History of Color in Europe
students.title: Rich History of Color in Europe

students.description: Each country has a unique ring that resents the proportion of each ceramic type in The Met ceramics collection. Each type of ceramics will have a different color representation and takes one slice indicating its proportion in all the ceramics from the corresponding country.
students.name: Zui Chen
students.subtitle: Ring of Ceramics
students.title: Ring of Ceramics

students.description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has made nearly 500,000 pieces of art publicly available through its online collection. Anyone with access to a browser can now view the collection’s images virtually. However, when we view these images in a virtual space, we lose the sense of scale we get when we visit the museum in person. This visualization explores a subset of The Met’s online collection in which scale plays a large role in the viewer experience: sculptures of human subjects.
students.name: Marisa Ruiz Asari
students.subtitle: Sculptures of Scale
students.title: Sculptures of Scale

students.description: Have you ever seen over 9k ceramics surface at the same time? This is a web-based lookbook for The Met ceramics. Each grid is a close-up zoom in of the object’s surface, providing extreme details of each object. The lookbook is ordered and categorized by the type of clay (different in ingredient and fire temperature): fritware, earthenware, stoneware, terracotta, porcelain, pottery, ceramic, and other.
students.name: Zui Chen
students.subtitle: The Met Ceramics Lookbook
students.title: The Met Ceramics

students.description:
I am interested in forms of Catholic art, and The Met collection is rich and deep in this area.  In fact, The Met's collection is so deep, it can be overwhelming to a casual observer.

I felt much of this sacred art is removed from its original context.  Many of The Met's objects have been presented in Cathedrals, and some even adorned high altars, making many of them central to worship.

I wanted to see if using The Met's digital collection I could present the artwork within a narrative framework, and restore the potential for these items to be used as meditative aids.    The Rosary was the perfect vehicle;  it provides both narrative and a prayer context, and it has been used for centuries, including in our present day.   Many people at least may have heard of a Rosary,  even if they do not fully understand what it is or how it works.   Thus a third goal is established; to relate the art to a devotional practice in current use.
students.name: Douglas Locke
students.subtitle: The Met Rosary: Catholic Art at The Met
students.title: The Met Rosary

students.description:
— Making history visible
The documentation of important historical creates famous iconographic artifacts. Almost everybody has seen the images of the first moon landing taken by Neil Armstrong, or the first image of the earth known as »blue marble«.
The engagement with The Met’s open access collection shows that the museum is also in possession of such iconographic documentation, although a lot of it is little known by public . 
Around 40 paintings by the Painter Robert Charles Dudley document the laying of the first transatlantic cables in the middle of the 18th century, a huge technological mission with impacts on the interconnected and global society we are today.

— Paintings as diagrams
The goal of the visualization is to let the user enjoy the effects of the beautiful paintings and to augment these paintings with contextual and historical content at the same time. The paintings, grouped thematically, can be navigated as maps; the possibility to zoom gives the user control how to view the artifacts and clickable legends provide more insights about the contents of the paintings.
students.name: Robin Coenen
students.subtitle: Too fast for the truth — The laying of the first atlantic telegraph cable
students.title: Too Fast for the Truth

students.description: 30 years since the inception of The Guerrilla Girls infamous poster, I began to question how has The Metropolitan Museum of Art progressed? Do the values of gender inequality and female subjectification still stand true?  In a two-part project I explored this topic by creating an interactive desktop-based data visualization and a mock-up of a mobile application.
students.name: Lulu Tanenbaum
students.subtitle: Undress for The Met
students.title: Undress for The Met

students.description: An experiment using existing art to make new art. And a new way to experience art. For this project I chose four 2D works of art from across a range of eras and departments at The Metropolitan Museum of Art and rendered each of them as a landscape or topographic map. I used Rembrandt’s Self Portrait, Cow's Skull: Red, White, and Blue by Georgia O'Keeffe, Elegy to the Spanish Republic No. 70 by Robert Motherwell, and A Rose by Thomas Anshutz. The final poster series shows each painting from straight-on (top down if you’re thinking in 3D) isometric perspectives. The framing around the straight-on image indicates what the image looks like from all four sides. These images were then taken into Unity to create navigable landscapes in which the user can walk around the works of art.
students.name: Brad MacDonald
